title: Looking Up: Front Exterior Germantown YWCA, 2024
creator: Cameron L. Boucher
description: Front exterior view of Germantown YWCA looking upwards from the entrance. Decorative original wood trim surrounding door is partially visible. All windows are covered with what is known as “faux windows” or decorative board-ups designed to mimic real windows and hide broken glass, missing wood, etc. of severely damaged vacant buildings.

title: “Women of Germantown” Mural, YWCA Building 2024
creator: Alice McGrath
description: A side view of the Germantown YWCA building taken from the sidewalk showcasing the "Women of Germantown" mural painted by artist David McShane of Philadelphia Mural Arts Project in 2001. A chain link fence surrounds a grassy lot next to the vacant YWCA; it is adorned with the word “VOTE!.” It is a large fiber art project by Kathryn Pannepacker of Germantown.  The mural has begun to deteriorate. Missing masonry can be seen and it is partially covered by vines.
subject: Community Centers; Preservation; Architecture; Vacant YWCA; Fires; Germantown Settlement; Philadelphia Redevelopment Authority (PRA)
rights: CC BY
image_alt_text: Image of Germantown YWCA from a side perpective showing the "Women of Germantown" by artist David McShane.

title: Distant View “Women of Germantown” mural, YWCA 2024
creator: Alice McGrath
description: A distant side view of the Germantown YWCA Building taken from the sidewalk focused on the "Women of Germantown" mural completed by artist David McShane in October, 2001. The mural has images of six women connected to the YWCA and Germantown. They are Maggie Kuhn, Clarice Herbert, “Dinah,” Sadie Tanner Alexander, Lucretia May Alcott and Sarah W. McLean. In the background, part of Maple Village, a senior residence can be seen. In the foreground is a chain link fence with two fiber art projects hanging on it; one says “VOTE!” and the other “Breathe Justice.” There are also dumped tires in the grass.
subject: Community Centers; Preservation; Architecture; Vacant YWCA; Fires; Germantown Settlement; Philadelphia Redevelopment Authority (PRA)
rights: CC BY
image_alt_text: Image of Germantown YWCA from a side perpective showing the "Women of Germantown" by artist David McShane.

title: Major Fire at Vacant Germantown YWCA Building, 2012
creator: Bastiaan Slabbers
description: A photograph of the vacant Germantown YWCA building during a major fire on January 1, 2012. Two fire engines and two fire fighters can be seen in front of the building. One large image from the edge of the iconic “Women of Germantown mural is visible. It is Sarah W. McLean. Ironically, she was a philanthropist who financed the historic building, known as “The Administration Building” when it opened in 2015; she is shown holding a miniature of the front entrance.
subject: Fires; Architecture; Vacant YWCA ; Germantown Settlement; Philadelphia Redevelopment Authority (PRA)
rights: This material is in copyright and is used with permission from WHYY.
image_alt_text: Image of the Germantown YWCA building during the fire incident with emergency vehicles and firefighters working to make sure the fire is extinguished as the fire hose is still out.

title: Children and Youth outside "Colored" Branch YWCA Germantown
description:
The “Colored Branch” of the Germantown YWCA was housed at 6128 Germantown Ave from 1918 to1952. Beginning in 1946, after the national YWCA passed its “Interracial Charter,” the programs, staff and membership of the Germantown YWCA at 5820 and the Branch Y began to gradually merge. This integration was completed in 1952 when the Branch’s building at 6128 was
permanently closed and later sold.
subject: African American children; Community centers
rights: This material is subject to copyright law and is made available for private study, scholarship, and research purposes only. title: Questionnaire page 1
creator: Germantown Branch YWCA
description: Document/Survey
subject: Branch Y; Race
rights: This material is subject to copyright law and is made available for private study, scholarship, and research purposes only. For access to the original or a high resolution reproduction, and for permission to publish, please contact Temple University Libraries, Temple University Libraries, Special Collections Research Center, scrc@temple.edu, 215-204-8257.
image_alt_text: Scan of an archive document containing a questionnaire about integration at the YWCA, page 1
object_transcript:
Questionnaire Used in B&P Council

November 1944.

  1. Does the YWCA believe in no discrimination against Negroes? Yes – 14 No – 2 Don’t know – 1
  2. Do you think the Germantown YWCA discriminates against Negroes? Administration: Yes – 2 No – 13 Don’t know – 1 Participants: Yes – 10 No – 4 Don’t know - 2
  3. Have you ever worked on a project or a committee with Negro girls? Yes - 9 No - 6
  4. If so, do you think it a success or failure? Success – 5 Failure - 2 Don't know - 2
  5. Do you think there is any value in an occasional interracial project? Yes – 12 No - 2 Don't know - 1
  6. Do you think it practical for the club to plan a project together with girls at the Branch? Yes - 4 No - 12
  7. Why? Negative 12 Positive 3 Don't know – 1
    1. Would break down League membership
    2. We would just have a meeting and that would be as far as it would go. Impractical.
    3. Club too small to handle it.
    4. Don't believe Branch girls are interested in same activities as we have.
    5. Everyone might not be willing to cooperate.
    6. "Will not mix."
    7. Neither aide is ready to cooperate - take it gradually.
    8. Impractical - "all people do not feel the same about the problem."
    9. It is possible to work together and if the right type of project is used it could be a success.
    10. Impractical - "Previously we have not had much cooperation."
    11. Afraid it would take a little education on our part.
    12. Too many girls are prejudiced and are not able to act graciously.
    13. "Practical because it would tend to bring about cooperation end understanding and a better community feeling."
    14. Don't think this type of meeting of any value to either group.
    15. Practical "because it would aid in learning to work together for necessary times."
  8. If such a project were planned would you be willing to cooperate? Yes - 11 No - 3 Possibly - 2
  9. What are some of the problems or difficulties that arise in a joint project?
    1. Lack of mutual Interest.
    2. Would have to overcome natural race hatred.
    3. They have leas education. They don't see our point of view. Some think we are above them; others think we are beneath them.
    4. People afraid to try a something new not knowing what other people will think.

title: Questionnaire page 2
creator: Germantown Branch YWCA
description: Document/Survey
subject: Branch Y; Race
rights: This material is subject to copyright law and is made available for private study, scholarship, and research purposes only. For access to the original or a high resolution reproduction, and for permission to publish, please contact Temple University Libraries, Temple University Libraries, Special Collections Research Center, scrc@temple.edu, 215-204-8257.
image_alt_text: Scan of an archive document containing a questionnaire about integration at the YWCA, page 2
object_transcript:
1. cont.
    1. Ideas different. Too many things to consider. May be hard feelings.
    2. Too much prejudice on both sides. Negroes held down so long they seem to resent interference.
    3. Personal feelings.
    4. People don't know what to talk about. Everyone is not willing to go out of their way to make other races feel at ease. Makes a strained situation.
    5. People still too prejudiced.
    6. Don't know.
    7. Different social levels, real and imaginary.
  2. Do you think there is any connection between a project planned and executed by a mixed group of business girls and postwar peace? Yes - 11 No - 0 Don't know - 3 Afraid So - 1 Heard so - 1

  3. If a white girl and a Negro girl who have equal skills in typing and shorthand apply for the same job, who should be hired? White - 8

    Negro - 0

    Girl with additional qualifications such as personality, good appearance, etc. - 4

    Don't know - 2

    Depends on policy of employer - 1

  4. If a white girl with good and no experience and a Negro girl with good and 3 years experience should apply for the earn job, which should be hired? White - 4 ​​Negro – 10​​ Either – 1
  5. Do you think that your feelings about Negroes are based on:
    1. Personal knowledge – 5
    2. Information from others – 1
    3. Scientific Fact – 0 1 & 2 – 3 1 & 3 – 3 2 & 3 – 2 1, 2 & 3 – 1
  6. Do you think you are prejudiced against Negroes? Yes – 7​​ No - 5 ​​A little – 4
  7. Do you believe your attitudes are good enough so that you do not want to change then? Yes - 9​​ No – 7
  8. Does this YWCA have a policy regarding the facilities of the building for the use of Negroes? Yes – 3​​ No - 1​ Don't know – 11​ Yes and No – 1
  9. If so, what is it?
    1. No racial discrimination
    2. No swimming in the pool
    3. Does let them use pool
    4. Negroes free to use facilities of building

title: Letter regarding convention
creator: Phyllis Wheatley Branch YWCA
description: A copy of a letter addressed to Miss Bowles (Eva Del Vakia Bowles) from the Executive Secretary of a Phyllis Wheatley Branch YWCA regarding an upcoming convention.
subject: Branch Y; Race
rights: This material is subject to copyright law and is made available for private study, scholarship, and research purposes only. For access to the original or a high resolution reproduction, and for permission to publish, please contact Temple University Libraries, Temple University Libraries, Special Collections Research Center, scrc@temple.edu, 215-204-8257.
image_alt_text: Scan of an archive letter regarding convention proceedings
object_transcript:
Phyllis Wheatley Branch Y.W.C.A. March 12, 1928

Dear Miss Bowles: 

I am enclosing our Branch report for the month of February. In reading over the National Board Report prior to the Sacramento Convention, which by the way, I find I am going to be able to attend, I have been much interested in noticing that so little is said of our Colored Work; even less, in fact, than in the Report to the Milwaukee Convention.

Also, in looking over the tentative program for the Convention sessions, there is no time devoted to our group. I realize perfectly that this exclusiveness is the ideal for which we should strive and that such an attitude has made it possible to go very far in race relations, further, perhaps, than some other organizations. Yet from a local standpoint, we are still working with colored women in Branches, and, perhaps, even for a few years longer there will be Branches; moreover, the whole field of race relations difficulty is not settled as is so often experienced when we feel that we have gone forward and instances of misunderstanding arise.

The whole problem of understanding seems to me so big that I wonder if it is not important enough to have some consideration on Convention Agenda. I realize, however, how tired we all become of race considered over and over, again as a problem just as we do of sex, than focussing attention on one phase. Nevertheless, the working of such a machinery as the Committee on Colored Work - which by the way, we do not have - is so much in the process of flux that, perhaps, some of us could at least gain help from a pooling of experiences and a statement of ideals of race relations.

Our place as an interracial organization in the community is another phase of the same question. Often it is forgotten that we are doing interracial work because we act rather than talk of our activities.

Then, finally, there is membership representation of our group. In other words, these three phases of our problem which I have mentioned, really all have to do with understanding between races. I should like to know if any other Branches feel as we do, the need for a place in the thinking of the Convention.

Hoping to hear from you soon, I am

Very truly yours,

Executive Secretary

title: Branch Y Activities Secretary Job Posting Page 1
creator: Germantown Branch YWCA
description: Photographs of two pages from a job posting for an Activities Secretary position at the Germantown Branch YWCA in 1942.
subject: Branch Y; Race
rights: This material is subject to copyright law and is made available for private study, scholarship, and research purposes only. For access to the original or a high resolution reproduction, and for permission to publish, please contact Temple University Libraries, Temple University Libraries, Special Collections Research Center, scrc@temple.edu, 215-204-8257.
image_alt_text: Archive job posting looking for an activities secretary at the Colored Branch
object_transcript:
Place ----- Germantown Branch Y.W.C.A.

Job To Be Filled ----- Activities Secretary. 

When ----- February 1942.

Salary ----- 1,200

Is there a retirement fund ----- Yes.

Name of person ----- Miss S. Lavina Moore.

Date of leaving ----- February 20, 1942

Reason ----- To become Health Education Director in another Association

Name & Address of person carrying

                  Mrs. Herbert T. Miller (Belle Miller) Mrs. Hazel Baker

                  Y.W.C.A. 6128 Germantown Avenue.

                  The Staff consists of the Executive Secretary, Activities Director, one full time Office Secretary and two part-time clerical workers. 

                  The Activities Secretary is responsible for the promotion of sports particularly badminton, tennis, horseback riding and skating. In addition to this, she is to work as advisor to one Girl Reserve Club, and one Industrial Club. She is responsible for coordination of all sports at the Branch and must be able to work in close cooperation with the Central Y.W.C.A. of Germantown. One problem which the Association has faced is in regard to weekend skating and dancing parties. It has been necessary to establish a name file as a means of checking on the type of persons who attend affairs at the Branch. This condition has perhaps improved some, but is still in the process of being thoroughly worked out. Some attention must be given to the question of the Tennis Courts; which problem may no doubt take a few years in order to be worked out adequately. The presence of the 76th Artillery Unit in this vicinity makes it increasingly important for Industrial girls to have special guidance as to how to accept the presence of the soldiers without becoming fully overwhelmed by them.

title: Activities Secretary Job Posting Page 2
creator: Germantown Branch YWCA
description: Document
subject: Branch Y; Race; Events
rights: This material is subject to copyright law and is made available for private study, scholarship, and research purposes only. image_alt_text: Archive job posting looking for an activities secretary at the Colored Branch
object_transcript:
Is There A Chairman ----- Yes – Younger Girl’s Committee

Board Member ----- Yes.

Committee ----- No Industrial Committee, but committee chairman – not a member of the board.

Make-Up ----- Younger Girl’s Committee – Chairman – active on committees at both the Central Association and the Branch; has attended conferences at the National Board; extremely interested in progress in the Y.W.C.A. in relation to the Younger Girl’s Department --- housewife. 

Committee members:

  1. Teacher now retired due to marriage – young, college graduate – former Girl Reserve advisor in Dayton, Ohio.

  2. College Graduate, major in group work, at the present time doing volunteer work with the Younger Girl’s Department at the Branch – Unemployed.

  3. Teacher at the Morgan Teacher’s College

Qualifications:

                  College Graduate – preferably a Physical Education Major – some experience in group work – should be able to instruct tennis and badminton – should have some camp experience. It is important to have some experience in dealing with Interracial groups. 

February 1942 

Thelma Wamble, Executive.

title: Business Exhibit Flyer Branch Y
creator: Colored Branch of YWCA of Germantown
description: A document/Invitation to a multi-day, second annual business exhibit at the Colored Branch of the YWCA of Germantown focused on sewing, hairstyling, consumer information, finances and more, plus a fashion show with an orchestra. Does not specify what year it was, however attendance fee is only 25 cents each night.

object_transcript:
Second Annual Business Exhibit

Open each day from 10:00 A.M. to 10:00 P.M.

Branch Y.W.C.A

6128 Germantown Ave.

Thursday Night Nov. 10

Come and See

A dress made in fifteen minutes!

The latest styles of Fair Dressing for Street, Afternoon, and Evening!

How to get a frigidaire cheap & 

How to save money on flowers!

How to launder the best and easiest way!

The scientific way to cook!

All these and other demonstrations with an Orchestra Thursday

Friday Night Nov. 11

Big Fashion Show – Models:

                  E. Howard Dress Shop – 18 & Addison St.

                  Sally’s Shop

                  Stylish Stout

                  Stylish Thin

                  Charming Bride

                  Pajamas – Street

                  Etc.

Orchestra Friday night also

Admission 25¢ each night

title: YWCA of Germantown Colored Branch Building, 6128 G’town Ave
creator: Germantown Branch YWCA
description:
This building housed what was commonly called the “Colored Branch” or “Branch Y” from 1918 until its closure in 1952 and subsequent sale a few years later. Beginning in 1946, after the
national YWCA passed an “Interracial Charter,” the programs, staff and membership of the Germantown YWCA at 5820 and the Branch Y began to gradually merge. This merger was completed in 1952 when 6128 was closed.
subject: Branch Y; Architecture; Race
rights: This material is subject to copyright law and is made available for private study, scholarship, and research purposes only. title: Damaged YWCA Pool post Sale Fires (2006-2012)
creator: John Webster
description: “Germantown Women’s Y,” functioned from 1999 to about 2005; Germantown Settlement/Greater Germantown Community Development Corporation (GGCDC) purchased the YWCA building in 2006. It never reopened. Following Settlement’s 2010 bankruptcy, the building was reclaimed by Redevelopment Authority (RDA) – now PRA – as it had loaned 1.3 million for purchase. Between 2006 and 2014, the vacant, unsealed building was devastated by vandalism and fires.
subject: Swimming; Fires
rights: This material is in copyright and is used with permission from the creator.

title: Swimmers Germantown YWCA Junior Girls’ Day Camp, 1947
creator: Philadelphia Evening Bulletin
description: A photograph of Betty Shreiner leads the first swimming class for teenagers at the Germantown YWCA swimming pool for the Junior Girls' Day Camp. Just a year after the formerly segregated, all-white YWCA at 5820 Germantown  Ave., opened all of its facilities and programs to all races, we see a partially integrated group from the Junior Girls’ Day Camp receiving instructions in the swimming pool.

title: “Swim Here” early pamphlet, Germantown Y
creator: YWCA of Germantown
description: While there is no date on this pamphlet, the text and prices indicate this was in the early years or first decades of the pool which opened in 1915.  For example, private lessons were 6 for $7.00.  It was still required to be examined by a doctor annually to have access to the pool. And, sterilized suits provided by the YWCA were required as were bathing caps!
subject: Swimming; Programs

title: Three photos found in wreckage after fires at YWCA
creator: John Webster
description: Three damaged photographs found in fire-damaged Germantown YWCA Building.  The left one appears to be the first floor lounge and lobby area. The right room appears to be on an upper floor. It looks like a reading room or a club room. The final photo is outdoors and can only be seen partially. Based on cobblestones and tracks and single building, it appears to be Germantown Ave. Most likely, it was the 5800 block where the YWCA was and remains located.

title: Broken unsealed windows YWCA 2015
creator: Jill Saull
description: A photograph showing unsealed and broken windows on the front exterior of the Germantown YWCA Building in February 2015. (This follows the sale of the building to Germantown Settlement/Greater Germantown Community Development Corporation in 2006 with 1.3 million loan from the Philadelphia Redevelopment Authority (PRA) and $500,000 from the State of PA. Settlement went bankrupt in 2010, but the building was neither reopened nor sealed after the purchase. This photograph was taken after vandalism and fires in 2010 and 2012. After the second fire, the building was declared “imminently dangerous” and the PRA said it might need to be demolished.
subject: Architecture; Fires; Vacant YWCA ; Germantown Settlement; Philadelphia Redevelopment Authority (PRA); Found Memorabilia; Germantown Women’s Y (GWY)

title: First Sketch of “The Women of Germantown” Mural
creator: David McShane
description: Image of first design for “The Women of Germantown” Mural painted and photographed by artist David Mc Shane of Philadelphia Mural Arts Project.  This was presented to a committee from the Germantown Women’s Y, the group that ousted the Board of the YWCA in May, 1999. They were unhappy with the formality of the design as represented by an ancient Greek portico with columns separating each of the six women who were chosen from a list of 50. The women represented from left to right are: Clarice Herbert, first African-American woman to become Executive Director of YMCA of Germantown (shown with hands on Black child’s shoulders);Maggie Kuhn, Secretary for Professional and Business Women at the YWCA, 1930 – 1941, later founder of Gray Panthers (shown with a Panther sign and raised fist); Sadie Tanner Alexander, first African-American woman to go to Penn Law School (shown holding scales of justice); Sarah W. McLean, early YWCA philanthropist and leader (shown holding miniature YWCA building); Louisa May Alcott, suffragist, abolitionist and writer born in building first rented by YWCA of Germantown in 1870’s (shown holding book and writing implement); and lastly “Dinah” an enslaved then freed worker at Stenton Mansion which she saved from being burned by the British during the Revolution (shown holding fire-lit lantern). A local woman – Irma Gardner-Hammond portrayed Dinah; all others were done from photos.
subject: Mural; Germantown Women’s Y(GWY)
rights: This material is in copyright and is used with permission from the creator.
image_alt_text: Image of David McShane's first design for the Women of Germantown Mural

title: Planning the “Women of Germantown” Mural 2000 Pamphlet
creator: Germantown Women's Y
description: Image of page 28 from the Germantown Women’s Y (GWY) pamphlet announcing new organization running programs at the Germantown YWCA Building as of Spring, 1999 and upcoming classes and programs for fall and winter 2000-2001. The page in view is titled "Women's Mural" with a subsection “Women of Germantown.” It explains that a mural is planned for the wall of the building to be done in conjunction with “Mural Arts Program of the Department of Recreation.” It lists 42 women who might appear on the mural and states that the project has goals beyond the mural.  These are to create a “Research Project and Book” for use in the Philadelphia Public School System. Among the 42 names listed are the six women whose images appear on the finished mural: Maggie Kuhn, Dinah, Clarice Gamble Herbert, Sadie Tanner Alexander, Louisa May Alcott and Sarah W.B. McLean. All or most of the other names appear as a list across the bottom of the mural.
subject: Mural; Germantown Women's Y (GWY); "Women of Germantown” mural; Programs
source: Germantown Women’s Y (GWY) 2020-2021 Pamphlet, Germantown Historical Society
image_alt_text: Image of a page of the Germantown YWCA  Pamphlet from 2001 that mentions the "Women's Mural"

title: Mural Arts for Teens Germantown Women’s Y, 2000
creator: Germantown Women’s Y
description: Image of page 12 from the Germantown Women’s Y’s 2000-2001 pamphlet that mentions "The Big Picture: Mural Arts for Teens" program among many other “Classes, Workshops, Programs, Services, Special Events” scheduled for the fall and the winter to be held in the Germantown YWCA Building at 5820 Germantown Ave. This is described as a nine-month after school program with three phases starting in October 2000: “Phase One: Foundation, “Phase Two: Social Responsibility/Introduction to Mural Process” and “Phase Three: Community Mural Painting.” This pamphlet was created by the group of members that voted out the YWCA of Germantown Board in 1999 and formed the Germantown Women’s Y (GWY).
subject: Mural; Germantown Women’s Y (GWY); Programs
source: Germantown Women’s Y (GWY) 2020-2021 Pamphlet, Germantown Historical Society
image_alt_text: Image of page from the Germantown YWCA's fall 2000 pamphlet that mentions "The Big Picture: Mural Arts for Teens" program

title: YWCA of Germantown 1944 Integration Survey Part 1 & 2
description: The image shows photographs of two pages from a questionnaire about segregation and integration of YWCA of Germantown’s facilities (also refer to the Branch YWCA which existed until 1952). It is titled “Questionnaire Used in B&P Council November 1944.” Above the title in pencil, it says “Return to Riegel.” Between the two pages, there are 17 questions and answers (ranging from  simple yes and no’s to why’s with narrative explanations). The first question asks, “Does the YWCA believe in no discrimination against Negroes?” Question 14 asks, “Do you think you are prejudiced against Negroes?” Respondents can be “Administrators” or “Participants.” In this document, “Administrators” likely refers to YWCA staff. The “participants” likely means YWCA club/B&P Council members. (When multiple like-clubs existed, they often had a “council” connecting them.)  In this case, “B&P” likely stands for “Business and Professional” Women, which was a main constituent focus in addition to Industrial Clubs, which were strong in the YWCA’s early decades. The “Business and Professional” women’s clubs included clerical workers, saleswomen, bank tellers, etc. Maggie Kuhn, was the Secretary (YWCA term for Director or Coordinator) of the Business and Professional Women work at the YWCA of Germantown from 1930 to 1941. These surveys were filled out by approximately 27 administrators and 16 participants. Riegel refers to Marguerite L. Riegel* who was General Secretary (Executive Director) of the YWCA of Germantown from 1942-1946.
subject: Branch Y; Race; Programs
